title: 103_hr458
content: The "Financial Services Act of 1993" allows a subsidiary of a national bank to underwrite shares of and sponsor investment companies. Section 5136 of the Revised Statutes of the United States (12 U.S.C. 24) is amended to allow national banks to engage in dealing, underwriting, and distributing shares of investment companies through a nonbank subsidiary. This expands their activities beyond what is currently permitted. The amendment allows national banks to engage in activities through a subsidiary, defined as a corporation with over 25% voting stock owned by a national bank. This does not restrict national banks from participating in other activities directly. SEC. 3 amends the Federal Reserve Act to allow a subsidiary of a state member bank to underwrite shares of and sponsor investment companies. SEC. 4 introduces disclosure requirements for subsidiaries of national and state member banks. If a nonbank subsidiary of a national bank or State member bank engages in certain activities, it must provide customers with a written disclosure stating that it is not an insured depository institution, is a separate entity from any affiliated insured depository institution, and that products offered are not insured or guaranteed by the FDIC. The regulation requires insured depository institutions to obtain written acknowledgements from customers regarding disclosures. The method of disclosures must comply with regulations set by the Comptroller of the Currency or the Board. Exceptions and additional information may be required or exceptions granted by the respective regulatory bodies. The regulation allows exceptions to disclosure requirements if consistent with the purposes of the subsection. SEC. 5 amends the Banking Act of 1933 regarding member banks affiliating with companies underwriting shares and sponsoring investment companies. SEC. 6 authorizes member banks and affiliates engaged in investment activities to have management interlocks. Section 32 of the Banking Act of 1933 is amended to allow officers, directors, or employees of nonbank subsidiaries engaged in investment activities to also serve in affiliated banks or investment companies. The Banking Act of 1933 is amended to allow officers, directors, or employees of nonbank subsidiaries engaged in investment activities to also serve in affiliated banks or investment companies. This includes banks that are affiliates of the same bank or investment companies organized, sponsored, managed, or controlled by a subsidiary of the bank or holding company. Authorization for a bank holding company to establish a company underwriting shares of and sponsoring investment companies. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to include shares of companies dealing in investment companies. Disclosure requirements for these activities are also added. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to include disclosure requirements for companies involved in subsection (c)(15) activities. This includes a one-time written disclosure to customers stating that the company is not an insured depository institution, is separate from any affiliated insured depository institution, and that products offered are not insured by the FDIC. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to include disclosure requirements for companies involved in subsection (c)(15) activities. Companies must provide a one-time written acknowledgement to customers stating that they are not insured depository institutions, separate from any affiliated insured depository institution, and that their products are not insured by the FDIC. The disclosures must be made in accordance with regulations set by the Board, with exceptions and additional information as deemed necessary.
